messages: 050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7 (19:58): oh, I don't need to back that out of inbound the very second that I wake up, surely nobody will push on top of that
eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (19:58): 050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7, I wouldn't *dream* of pushing atop unstarred orange.
050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7 (20:01): the unstarredness isn't a problem, it's the way that several suites crash
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:05): regarding reveal or download scan
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:06): both
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:08): should finish off the moz-icon one
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:08): never got around to debugging the test failure
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:11): Are there any studies on the number of ms that should never happen on the UI thread?
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:11): I remember reading about a goal for the Windows team before but I can't remember what it was.  Maybe like 30ms or something
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:11): the goal we "have" is to return to the event loop every 50ms
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:12): ok that sounds fair
050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7 (20:14): http://quotes.burntelectrons.org/1627
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:15): 200ms is definitely noticeable though
050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7 (20:19): yeah, my build speed still isn't there, either

eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (20:19): 050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7, You'll need to launch off at relativistic speeds and then have your build beamed to you via ansible in order to get that fast.
eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (20:20): 050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7, Unfortunately, by the time you returned to earth, we'd be in the year 20,000 and Mozilla might be slightly less-relevant.
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:20): lies
df20fd9b3d8183511f306709b2b3056d (20:20): "20,000 years in space"?
050421e96671fe1a3d8cf2b5dbe99cb7 (20:20): probably have a lot of orange to star by then
df20fd9b3d8183511f306709b2b3056d (20:20): sounds like a novel
51c1edab440268cdb0754ff0c4584a9f (20:21): eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3: no we'll be relevent
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:21): Oh, no, we'll have dumped tests by then
439cdfaa2971ad446568f3d5a517e5d1 (20:21): In year 20,000, I hope that we number our versions in 128 bits.
51c1edab440268cdb0754ff0c4584a9f (20:21): eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3: we'll be developing firefox for your brain
51c1edab440268cdb0754ff0c4584a9f (20:21): and a REALLY REALLY long version number
51c1edab440268cdb0754ff0c4584a9f (20:21): that would be some subset of the fibbonacci sequence
51c1edab440268cdb0754ff0c4584a9f (20:22): at least we'll no longer need to support OSX10.7
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:22): 439cdfaa2971ad446568f3d5a517e5d1: why, 32 bits will be more than sufficient

f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:22): khuey: Is there another class that is similar to LazyIdleThread but designed for a single event to be processed?  So basically the same but you wouldnt' have to specify a default timeout.
67b8dbbd954f99b0be64bce6b421d195 (20:22): but it wouldn't be hard to bolt on, I think
f220ec2826047dc2f88de18ac4db4f42 (20:23): meh not worth it :)
439cdfaa2971ad446568f3d5a517e5d1 (20:23): khuey: that's because you assume that we will not have stepped up the rapid release rhythm :)
6fda27264f8154abdb6ed31bd701a8e5 (20:25): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: there's a running gag about pivotaltracker.com, or i missed smth subtle ? :)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:27): 6fda27264f8154abdb6ed31bd701a8e5, nah, some people apparently want to hide their stuff from the rest of us in bugzilla
6fda27264f8154abdb6ed31bd701a8e5 (20:28): what a strange idea...
c737003d3a0b95365e7613f7a72916b7 (20:48): hello, where should i look/read to get more idea  to use the
c737003d3a0b95365e7613f7a72916b7 (20:48): moz-icon decoder to get the data in an image container ? i am doing a mentored bug and i have been adviced to use that
